articles.headline: Criticism of State-Owned Air India Grows
articles.snippet: Pilots are choosing not to fly for the airline and passengers are taking other flights, leading to big losses.
articles.abstract: Pilots are choosing not to fly for the airline and passengers are taking other flights, leading to big losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When Bob Haygooni paid a midflight visit to a cockpit at his new employer, Air India, he was shocked. The pilots, he said, had completely covered the windows with newspaper to keep out the sun.

articles.headline: New Mileage Stickers Include Greenhouse Gas Data
articles.snippet: New window stickers will compare a vehicle’s emissions of carbon dioxide with those of all other vehicles.
articles.abstract: New window stickers will compare a vehicle’s emissions of carbon dioxide with those of all other vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government unveiled new fuel economy window stickers on Wednesday, for vehicles starting with the 2013 model year, that for the first time include estimated annual fuel costs and the vehicle’s overall environmental impact.

articles.headline: Suspect in Shooting of Giffords Ruled Unfit for Trial
articles.snippet: A federal judge ruled Jared L. Loughner not mentally competent to stand trial on charges that he opened fire at a constituent event for an Arizona congresswoman in January, killing six.
articles.abstract: A federal judge ruled Jared L. Loughner not mentally competent to stand trial on charges that he opened fire at a constituent event for an Arizona congresswoman in January, killing six.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — A federal judge ruled Wednesday that Jared L. Loughner was not mentally competent to stand trial on charges that he opened fire at a constituent event for Representative Gabrielle Giffords in January, killing six and injuring her and 12 others.

articles.headline: Signs Grow That Palin May Run
articles.snippet: Sarah Palin is fortifying her staff of advisers, buying an Arizona home and adding public appearances.
articles.abstract: Sarah Palin is fortifying her staff of advisers, buying an Arizona home and adding public appearances.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sarah Palin is fortifying her small staff of advisers, buying a house in Arizona — where associates have said she could base a national campaign — and reviving her schedule of public appearances. The moves are the most concrete signals yet that Ms. Palin, the former governor of Alaska, is seriously weighing a Republican presidential bid.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: A Library of Listening, Made by You
articles.snippet: A Web site, DAR.fm, offers consumers a free service that is like TiVo for radio, with access to music, religion, sports and even political talk.
articles.abstract: A Web site, DAR.fm, offers consumers a free service that is like TiVo for radio, with access to music, religion, sports and even political talk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Want to know the real problem with the digital age? There’s not enough to listen to.

articles.headline: Chasing Riches From Africa to Europe and Finding Only Squalor
articles.snippet: Thousands of immigrants who were lured to Spain by dreams of easy money and a better life now live in encampments in the woods.
articles.abstract: Thousands of immigrants who were lured to Spain by dreams of easy money and a better life now live in encampments in the woods.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALOS DE LA FRONTERA, Spain — Back home in Gambia, Amadou Jallow was, at 22, a lover of reggae who had just finished college and had landed a job teaching science in a high school.

articles.headline: Serbia Says Jailed Mladic Will Face War Crimes Trial
articles.snippet: After 15 years, Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb general accused of ordering the massacre of Muslims in 1995, was captured. He will be sent to The Hague for trial.
articles.abstract: After 15 years, Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb general accused of ordering the massacre of Muslims in 1995, was captured. He will be sent to The Hague for trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb general held responsible for the massacre of some 8,000 Muslim men and boys at Srebrenica in 1995, was arrested on Thursday, signaling Serbia’s intention of finally escaping the isolation it brought on itself during the Balkan wars, the bloodiest in Europe since World War II.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Doreen Carvajal
